text: the situation in Japan is kind of the
best of situations and the worst of
situations at the same time Japan has
three attributes that make it one of the
country's most able to deal with this
kind of extraordinary event they have
wealth they have technology
technological capacity and they have
motivation and the motivation is because
there's enough a kind of garden-variety
earthquake activity in Japan you know
five point OS and six point OS that that
are pretty significant elsewhere but
there they give them a resilience
robustness and a motivation to make sure
they invest in their buildings and in
their planning now there are other
places in the world that have two out of
three they have wealth and technology
but not motivation and one of them is
the pacific northwest of the united
states there's a fault offshore called
the Cascadia fault it's been sitting
there dormant the last time there was a
great quake there was in the year 1700
and interestingly enough the only reason
we know is because it generated tsunamis
that were recorded in Japan the problem
of course is once every 300 years is not
the kind of frequency that makes
politicians or the public pay attention
in the state of Oregon alone there are
more than 1,000 schools public schools
that have been assessed by engineers as
very likely to be severely damaged or to
collapse when that next cascaded quake
occurs so what I hope between the chile
quake and this quake and several others
that have happened in recent years I'm
one can only hope that the message
starts to sink in
